Cowboy Carter isn‚Äôt just a good album, it‚Äôs a history thesis right from the 1st song. It‚Äôs a paradigm shifter and the most deserving AOTY in recent memory. What other album can claim to have birthed other artists success in a locked genre? Shaboozy doesn‚Äôt get his record breaking summer hit without Cowboy Carter.

author: @Whitneyinthegarden
text: My old boss is a white man and he went to Coachella in 2018 and he was able to see Beyonce. He was never a fan and still technically isn‚Äôt but he told me that he understands why people love Beyonce! He was like ‚ÄúI didn‚Äôt know any of the words but I was dancing along and had a good time‚Äù lol anyways he said her live performance changed his perspective and he appreciates her as an artist

replies.author: @PHlophe
replies.text: He was trying to be "down"

replies.author: @shirin9452
replies.text:
It‚Äôs funny cause she‚Äôs never been my fav (was too young to appreciate the glory that was having Destiny‚Äôs Child in my youth and also like 3 fire albums in my preteen years), but I watched a concert one time with my mom back in the 2010s on tv, one of the big ones, and it was the most insane experience ever. She looked like a golden goddess twirling on the edge of the stage with the whole world roaring. I remember being like oh my gosh. No WONDER people are so crazy about her. That is a  s t a r 
Then many years later Lemonade came out and I loved it SO much that I almost became part of the Hive lmao. I was just like I‚Äôm in, I‚Äôd always thought she was stunning but I was like if it‚Äôs like this yall I have been blind to the wonders of Beyonc√©. She never again hit what I saw in Lemonade and I think it‚Äôs just because I personally wanted what I saw. The aesthetic, the beats, the righteous cold anger of a woman who had sacrificed everything. Gorgeous fashion. Black culture. I was just entranced. And I made the mistake of thinking if she didn‚Äôt do that again it was inferior. But like‚Ä¶the other day I heard Deja Vu and I was like we did not appreciate what we had growing up üò≠

author: @Kadazia
text: 31:18 THANK YOU. And also, regardless of if you enjoy Cowboy Carter or not as a body of work, as an album and piece of art it is flawless. Yes she should have received AOTY for Self Titled, Lemonade and Renaissance but she ALSO rightfully won it for Cowboy Carter. All four albums were the best project in the category each year they were nominated. The quality of Cowboy Carter was the peak of the year. From the track list, to the vocals, the instrumentation, the story, the cultural impact, the performance potential. The quality is ALWAYS there. And I‚Äôm not even a hive member! Never been to a concert or bought merch. The talent is just undeniable.

replies.author: @ChristopherSadlowski
replies.text: I was going to write that I will never deny Beyonce is one of the most talented musical artists ever but she kinda annoys me. As I sit here thinking about it though, what actually annoys me is a really small part of her fan base. It's the same exact thing for me with Taylor Swift. She doesn't annoy me, a small handful of her fans do. If I set them aside, I actually really admire Beyonce and Taylor for the work they do. This industry is a FUCKING üëè NIGHTMARE üëè and they both navigate it with grace and diplomacy without getting ground to dust.

author: @barak-rocky-giles2081
text:
2:03 The craziest part about the Babyface/Chappell Roan situation is that (aside from it just being a rude thing to do to anyone) it was dumb as hell from a professional sense for those interviewers to do that. Babyface has access to a lot of artist these hosts would kill to have an exclusive interview with. (For context) Babyface is the kind of artist that if Chappell had an album flop or couldn't figure out how to finish her next album, her label would beg Babyface to come in and save the day.

P.S. Streisand would definitely get a ton of outrage as well. She may not be as recognizable to the younger generations as Babyface (only because his biggest impact is still very recent) however all real musicheads and students/lovers of music (even young ones) know that she is legit (solid film career as well).

author: @zackwilson8701
text: Cowboy Carter's biggest issue is that it's long and overwhelming for the first couple of listens. You can listen to Renaissance a million times without ever pressing skip. Cowboy Carter has some of the very best songs in her discography, though. If y'all haven't listened to II Hands II Heaven, Ya Ya, Bodyguard, II Most Wanted, Sweet Honey Buckiin, Tyrant, American Requiem, etc you're missing out. Especially the second half of the album feels a lot like Renaissance and has R&B or hip hop elements. She has not missed a step since 4.

author: @aquaintsound
text:
I think it is telling that Doechii is being stripped of her sexuality - Doechii has been loud and queer in her music. So seeing people strip her more overtly sexual music from her iconic discography has me extra heated. 

No hate to this group but i felt like lt was missing from the conversation aside from  a mention of lesbianism at 59:42 by Rebecca Azor 

Dark skinned Black women already have to fight for recognition - being queer and loud about it makes shit even harder. Because white queer women will flock to other white women but overlook or insult doechii. 

Doechii also takes the time to bring other folks up with her without disparaging sex work, gender non-conforming and trans folks, and acknowledging where she comes from. Janelle mon√°e is in thst same loud and queer umbrella being nonbinary is still recent as hell too and most folls just default to she/her and try to erase that queerness too - and Janelle still mostly gets nominated without winning. 

Yeah, Cardi is Bi but she doesnt talk about it much, distances herself from sex workers, and the WAP performance was made for the male gaze, not for queer women. I give Cardi a lot of credit and i understand that shes a person - she shouldnt have to stand for things as a token. And thats why giving flowers to out queer and Black artists who choose to lift up the queer community matters a lot. It can be both

author: @savagecomanche
text: I haven't listened to cowboy Carter yet because I just generally don't like pop-country but y'all convinced me to give it a listen, still mostly meh on it but that is the most beautiful rendition of blackbird

author: @annas.8504
text: Omg thank you for shouting out Glorilla‚Äôs Rain Down on Me, I love that song T.T

author: @puc-puggy
text: it's CRAZY that lemonade didn't win album of the year. a groundbreaking visual album that pulls a *poet laureate* to expand on the emotional center of the album and create a throughline between Black women's systemic oppression and their everyday lived experiences of disrespect, betrayal, and erasure in their personal relationships. the whole thing is just immaculate. "turning white flags blue"-- a blue flag is a flower native to louisiana & has been used as a symbol of Black femininity; turning surrender and defeat into a power that grows into its beauty. the visual nods to the Igbo Landing. "suicide before you see these tears fall down my eyes" nesting in the tradition of the Flying Africans and transmigration, death as an act of preservation and dignity. in 50 years, it's gonna be a landmark entry in the american literary canon. SHE should've got a pulitzer for it. and it's so satisfying that cowboy carter finally won, when country is a notoriously racist and exclusionary genre that has intentionally erased its own history of working class solidarity and its roots in struggle and was NEVER willingly gonna take her seriously. being a Black woman grounding her country album in histories of struggle and Black cowboys that were erased was an uphill climb & she deserved this win in a way few artists ever could. kendrick gets all the credit for consciouness raising because he's in rap and can pull on that tradition for immediate recognition. she's doing it from scratch in any genre she chooses. it's just excellent. nobody can take Beyonce's artistry from her

replies.author: @shirin9452

author: @jade2246
text: Babyface has given Madonna one of her biggest hits. He‚Äôs written and produced Fall Out Boy‚Äî- he‚Äôs a big deal regardless of being Black. She knew who he was and didn‚Äôt care to be professional about moving on to Roan.

author: @d.l.mhaoir.33
text: to quote CJ the X, ‚ÄúI‚Äôm on the side of good art.‚Äù I didn‚Äôt particularly enjoy Cowboy Carter. But I am sick of people saying, ‚ÄúBeyonc√© shouldn‚Äôt have won‚Äù and then not saying who should‚Äôve won and providing a valid argument. I mean I think Charli XCX should‚Äôve won bc brat had amazing production and was quite literally album of the summer whereas Cowboy Carter felt very gimmicky to me. But yeah a lot of the critique that wasn‚Äôt backed up by a valid counter argument just reeks of anti-blackness and misogynoir

replies.author: @khemikims4058
replies.text: I think cc deserved to win because it had amazing production, lyrics, history, and overlooked artists involved and funnily enough, I think brat was kinda gimmicky. Like with the lime green billboards appearing and the "secret" not so secret concerts to garner interest. Calling everything brat. I don't think the album would've survived without tiktok. Contrarily, cc had little to no marketing at all it kind of just organically gained traction. She had the superbowl ad in feb, it came out in march, she did the olympic ad in may and then, the winter halftime show in dec and that is the only promo it got. Anyone who doesn't care about sports learned of it through word of mouth.

replies.author: @d.l.mhaoir.33
replies.text: @ That‚Äôs a really good point. I don‚Äôt necessarily agree, but I see where you‚Äôre coming from.

replies.author: @ChristopherSadlowski
replies.text:
I'm mostly apathetic on the Grammys. I don't particularly think they're a great litmus test on the cultural impact around music. I personally feel all the awards shows bestow popularity rather than cementing an artist or work in something more timeless. However, I'm also not mad Cowboy Carter won; Beyonce for a while now has become VERY intentional in her work. It's about time that was recognized. 
What I'm NOT at ALL surprised over is the CMAs not recognizing the album. Like...not recognizing it so hard it might as well not even exist. The CMAs are so white they look like a Klan rally every time the camera pans the audience. The CMAs are so white they scare me.

replies.author: @nelsonmakay2522
replies.text: Nothing's more gimmicky than a reductive Dance record by Whyte girl..... Cowboy Carter is not even a typical country album & it challenged people's ears with it's genre bending fusions but hey we all have options & everyone is entitled to theirs

replies.author: @d.l.mhaoir.33
replies.text: @ i see where you‚Äôre coming from but Charli XCX isn‚Äôt white. she‚Äôs half white and half indian. also even though she‚Äôs white passing to us, she did get bullied quite a lot for being biracial

replies.author: @TakverReturns
replies.text:
‚Äã‚Äã@khemikims4058Agreed. I remember watching a Fantano review of Brat and noticed that most of his 'review' was waxing lyrically about the marketing around "brat" rather than the actual music which I personally found gimmicky and irritating.ü§∑üèæ‚Äç‚ôÄÔ∏è Those obnoxious billboards and "brat summer" or whatever left me cold.

By contrast, I didn't really see that much hype around CC, but even as a non-Beyonce fan, I know that she sang some country on Lemonade and that both Beyonce and Solange have showcased their Texas and country roots for a long time, anx it feels more like an organic interest rather than a gimmicky.

author: @eosinz

author: @bowardwoward22
text:
Growing up in Post-Katrina New Orleans: half of my music classes in middle school were watching and our old teacher appreciating various Beyonce concerts in between being bullied to join the school band to play "When the Saints Go Marching In" over and over again lmao. Her work may not have ever been for me, but I'll rep for Beyonce over any T-Swift or other weird white girly knock off any day of the week because even I cannot deny the cultural and qualitative gaps between B and the rest. You can't contest over 20 years of quality that, even at its worst, still towers above most others

-"A white punk rock kid who was in a garage band for approximately 45 minutes"

author: @TakverReturns
text:
I am 100% with Olay regarding professionalism in journalism. There is nowhere on THIS planet, at least, that a young, up-and-coming black journalist could get a job at AP or in music journalism and be *permitted* to not have some inkling of who Barbara Streisand was and her impact or stature, whether or not they 'identified' with her or found her "sooo relatable" or whatever.

The hypothetical that the (bottom left?) panelst introduced was not only absurd but incredibly irritating to hear. (And I get so tired of people telling me what they 'relate to' or what they 'identify' with as if it is a legitimate argument.)

She was there in the capacity of a journalist and interviewer...not a swooning fan girl. She is not being paid to put us on notice about who she personally identifies with. 

And that is precisely where white entitlement enters the fray. They always think that how they feel in any given moment and what they personally like is of vital importance and at the center of the universe; worse, everyone around them rushes to indulge them in this nonsense which is why they think its no big deal or acceptable.

Don't care how she got there and if she's a nep hire or social media personality. The job is the job, and if she's not qualified or able to do it, then she needs to get trained or step aside and let someone more qualified into the role.

We need to stop making excuses for these people when the entire world already rushes to coddle them.

And also...why interview someone you know nothing about? It's her JOB to do due diligence and basic research if she doesn't know. üôÑ

author: @XsweetstarliteX
text:
The ‚Äúdevil‚Äù has won the internet. Meaning the foreign bots, blackfishing, catfishing all to sow hate and division amongst groups is working well. Too many people believe they are speaking with honest real people online. They think that people actually mean what they say. Like these bots and paid actors online are not actively lying to weaken every ‚Äúprogressive‚Äù country.
Divide and conquer, its a tactic that works when there are fractures to begin with. These bots are able to make other black people turn against Beyonce because they press on the jealousy and misogynoir with the culture or within themselves. People lack critical thinking skills, you can critique without hating, bit first rule of being a critic is to be knowledgeable about what it is you are critiquing. Most of them have only heard  3 Beyonce songs. And cannot speak on the themes of the album. But they have an opinion. Imagine me talking about Lebron or Tom Brady but only seeing 3 games. üòÇ

author: @realtalk13
text: People who don't see the artistry of Beyonce just don't see it. And I'm not here to convince them of anything. But creating what essentially is an Afrofuturist reimagining of country and related genres, one in which black people were never excised from the genre, so our sounds of today are incorporated and weaved into the classic counds of Americana, country, folk? That's vision and artistry that few people can match in music right now. Beyonce remains one of the few artists in pop music that respects the album as a medium to tell a unified story and make a clear argument, and not just as a package of singles. And rewarding her for the album that epitomizes that philosophy the most makes sense to me. She absolutely deserved it for Self-titled, Lemonade, and Renaissance, and sonically, I do like some of those albums more than Cowboy Carter (it's very close, tbh) but artistry-wise, this album honestly is the most deserving of the bunch in my eyes.

text: The scarcity mindset is so evident in music, especially Black music, ESPECIALLY HIP HOP. That competition has always been there but it‚Äôs no longer constructive.

author: @showmethehoneybee
text:
lowkey as a Black genz I didn‚Äôt know BabyfaceüòÖ I just knew he dated/worked with Toni from Braxton Family Values‚Ä¶ I would be more starstruck by Chappell Roan. I‚Äôm queer and african and so identity informs who you hold dear. I don‚Äôt have the same kinship to the same African American ‚Äúlegends‚Äù  as when my music tastes is more global. 

BUT as a music fiend, ofc after some research I know babyfaces legacy. And it‚Äôs reasonal to expect an AP GRAMMY correspondent to be well researched. Why interview him at all?

as an african, we have utmost respect for elders. So to dismiss him for chappel who was born yesterday is rude. 

she was rude period. inexcusably so. and it‚Äôs still interesting to notice how you bring your identity to work, and why diversity in hiring is so important.
